title: Episode 06 – Safi Kaskas – Author, “Qur’an with References to the Bible”
subtitle: Sarah Arao Mantle of Hope- Thank You Video to the Y on Earth Community for GoFundMe Campaign Support
full_transcript:
[9.0s - 15.7s]: Hi friends, welcome to another edition of the Why on Earth communities stewardship and sustainability

[15.7s - 23.9s]: series. I'm so excited to have the opportunity today to speak with Dr. Sapi Koskas who joins us from

[23.9s - 31.9s]: Jeddah, Saudi Arabia, and Dr. Koskas travels all over the world speaking with political leaders,

[32.5s - 38.4s]: business leaders, and religious and spiritual leaders about a variety of essential topics to our

[38.4s - 46.0s]: time. In particular, he is doing work in the arena of cultural reconciliation,

[47.0s - 52.1s]: of focusing on healing and love between and among different peoples and cultures,

[53.3s - 59.4s]: and Sapi is such an honor and a pleasure to have this time with you today. Thank you so much for

[59.4s - 65.5s]: joining us. Thank you. I'm very happy to be able to speak to you. Thank you.

[66.8s - 74.1s]: Well, this is wonderful. I thought as a way to kick things off, I might mention to our viewers that

[74.7s - 81.5s]: Sapi co-authored a translation of the Quran with David Hungerford, and in it they,

[82.9s - 91.3s]: in their dedication, share a message I think that is so important to our times. I'm just going to

[91.3s - 97.5s]: read this really fast. It says this translation of the Quran is dedicated to our grandchildren,

[97.8s - 103.3s]: half of them Muslim, half of them Christian. If we as their adults do not learn how to live,

[103.3s - 109.8s]: love, and respect each other, and to pass this on to them and their parents, we will have allowed

[109.8s - 115.8s]: them to learn all the hate and fear that is so dominant in the world today. It is said that people

[115.8s - 122.1s]: fear what they don't understand. We pray that this translation of the Quran with references to the

[122.1s - 128.9s]: Bible will enable our grandchildren to share our understanding of the peaceful and inclusive

[128.9s - 136.4s]: holy books of the religions claimed by more than half the people on the planet, both of which promote

[136.4s - 144.0s]: God's love and mercy to all human beings. So Sapi, with that perhaps you could give us a bit of an

[144.0s - 148.4s]: introduction to the work that you're doing right now around the world and why it's so important.

[149.4s - 154.1s]: Well, I like to tell you a little bit about the translation to start with because that's the

[154.1s - 159.4s]: foundation of the work that I do. Actually, I spent six years working on the translation of the

[159.4s - 166.8s]: Quran. The reason I work on a new translation, there are over 200 translations you can find in any

[166.8s - 174.6s]: bookstore. The reason I did a new translation is simply because I didn't recognize the verses they

[174.6s - 183.0s]: are quoting on TV when they say this is the Quran. They talk about hateful things, they talk about how

[183.0s - 189.6s]: we're asked to kill all the infidels. The Quran doesn't ask me to do this, that's not the Quran I

[189.6s - 197.9s]: grew up with. So I decided enough is enough. I better do a translation in simple, easy to read,

[198.1s - 204.9s]: easy to understand English. So my translation is not directed, it's not targeting academic people,

[205.4s - 210.4s]: it's targeting my grandchildren and their friends. I really wanted them to understand

[211.4s - 219.0s]: the faith I have. I wanted them to be proud of the faith I have, rather than be ashamed of it.

[219.7s - 225.9s]: If my faith was something to be ashamed of, I would have left it myself. My faith includes

[225.9s - 233.2s]: believing in Jesus, my faith includes believing in Moses, believing in Abraham. Their faith is my

[233.2s - 239.5s]: faith. I don't have any faith coming from a different planet. I have a faith made for people

[239.5s - 247.5s]: who live on planet Earth. And this faith calls us to build bridges, rather than build walls around us.

[248.0s - 254.0s]: So I go around the world talking about what I found in those six years in the Quran. I thought I

[254.0s - 259.5s]: know the Quran very well. After six years working, trying to understand every word in Arabic,

[260.1s - 265.5s]: then finding an equivalent of that word in English, I think I know pretty well what the Quran's

[265.5s - 272.5s]: message is. The essence of the Quran is freedom. The essence is God telling us, you come to me with

[272.5s - 281.7s]: your free will, or I don't want you. Come to me freely. Submit your will to mine freely. Love each other

[281.7s - 289.5s]: freely. Do good work on Earth freely. Only this word that you do with your free will that come.

[289.5s - 295.4s]: And then at the end you come back to me. And I'm going to hold you responsible for whether you

[295.4s - 300.7s]: loved each other, whether you loved your neighbors, whether you loved your enemies, whether you lived

[300.7s - 306.7s]: in peace, or whether you worked for peace. It's not always possible for us to live in peace, but at least

[307.3s - 312.4s]: we can work for peace. So this is basically what I go around the world talking about.

[315.6s - 322.7s]: It's a message of bringing people together, reconciling, everybody talking about love rather than hatred.

[323.5s - 329.8s]: It's so important. It's so important in these times, in particular, Safi. And you know, I'm struck

[330.5s - 338.8s]: following your posts on Facebook and you are so good at documenting your journeys, your travels,

[338.8s - 343.8s]: your encounters with different people all around the world. And I remember I think this was

[343.8s - 351.3s]: earlier this year, maybe last year, a few months ago, seeing that at one part of the week you were

[351.3s - 357.2s]: meeting with some spiritual leaders in the Middle East. And then later a few days later you were

[357.2s - 362.9s]: meeting with some of the elders of the Mormon Church, probably I'm assuming out in Utah, I think it was.

[363.4s - 366.0s]: Yes, a brilliant young university and other places.

[366.7s - 376.4s]: Yes, and I was just so struck by when you mentioned bridge building that you are helping to plant

[376.4s - 381.7s]: the seeds of these conversations of love and peace in so many communities all over. And that

[381.7s - 390.2s]: when we get down to it, love and peace seem to be so central to these rich, religious and spiritual

[390.2s - 396.4s]: traditions that we have the opportunity to draw from. And I'm curious, when you're bringing that

[396.4s - 401.7s]: message to different communities, Safi, how is that received? How are people responding to that?

[403.1s - 411.2s]: People listen to me attentively. I've never had anybody violently oppose what I'm saying.

[412.1s - 419.3s]: I'm talking about basically loving God and loving neighbor. That's the essential message

[419.3s - 425.0s]: that I bring to others, especially in United States. We need that message. We need to implement that

[425.0s - 433.3s]: message. I mean, at one time I heard love God and love neighbor so much from my neighbors.

[434.2s - 439.6s]: So I went and did a little survey knocked on the door of every neighbor I have on a short street

[439.6s - 446.3s]: that I live on in the Washington DC area. And I said, do you love your neighbor? Say yes. How do you

[446.3s - 454.5s]: love your neighbor? They didn't know how to answer. What do you do? How do you express this love?

[455.2s - 461.5s]: Most people didn't know how to answer the question. So talking about loving neighbor is one thing.

[462.0s - 468.5s]: Practicing loving our neighbor is another thing. Let alone loving our enemies. We are far away

[468.5s - 474.8s]: from loving our enemies. We are so scared in the Western world in general, not just in United States,

[474.8s - 481.5s]: of the other. We're scared of the other. There is an industry that keeps feeding fear into us.

[482.2s - 488.9s]: One day I was speaking at a church in noon, in Georgia. And this old lady said, you said,

[489.0s - 494.0s]: do you live in Saudi Arabia? I said, yes. She said, would you tell me that truth? I said, yes.

[494.6s - 499.2s]: She said, is it true they're building boats and distributing weapons and they're going to come

[499.2s - 506.1s]: to our shores and shoot us? I said, man, the Saudi people are really just like us. They have families,

[506.1s - 511.2s]: they have children. They don't have time to think about us. They spend their time taking the

[511.2s - 517.7s]: children to school, going to the doctor, trying to make a living, buying groceries from the grocery

[517.7s - 524.3s]: store. They don't think much about us. You need to go and visit them. She said, is it safe to go there?

[524.3s - 531.0s]: I said, yes, it is safe. Thousands of Americans come and visit and then go back safely.

[531.6s - 540.2s]: It's very safe. So anyway, the message that I take to people is a message of love. The message

[540.2s - 547.5s]: they receive from some network, TV networks and from radios, especially on the radio in the afternoon,

[548.2s - 554.6s]: those talk shows their message of fears. They try to make people feel so fearful of the other.

[555.4s - 563.1s]: So now in the mind of some Americans, all Muslims are terrorists. Every Muslim is a suspect.

[563.7s - 569.9s]: Anybody speaking a language other than English is a suspect. This is not the way United States

[569.9s - 578.0s]: used to be. I came to United States in 1968. I'm a bicentennial citizen. I became a citizen in 1976.

[578.9s - 585.6s]: So I am very proud to say this and to repeat it. The United States I lived in at that time

[585.6s - 593.0s]: is not the same as the United States we live in today. Most likely people had racism,

[594.2s - 599.7s]: but it wasn't open. It wasn't obvious. They didn't share it openly.

[601.2s - 608.9s]: Now the atmosphere is kind of poison and I don't like this. I don't like to see this. I don't

[608.9s - 614.3s]: know what kind of place it's going to be for my grandchildren to grow in. I mean, we live there.

[615.2s - 621.1s]: You know, I'm here today, but my home is not here. It is in the Washington DC area. This is where I live.

[621.8s - 629.7s]: So, you know, it's just I care about what happens there. I want it to be a pluralistic country,

[630.3s - 637.7s]: not a diverse country. I know a street in Maryland where you have a Jewish synagogue, a Catholic church,

[638.2s - 647.1s]: a Baptist church and a Hindu temple, but those guys don't know each other. That street has diversity,

[647.8s - 654.2s]: but doesn't have pluralism. People don't talk to each other. I want Americans to sit together with

[654.2s - 660.2s]: each other and say, this is what I believe in and I have the Constitution to protect me.

[661.0s - 665.6s]: So let me explain to you my beliefs. Regardless whether you agree with them or not,

[665.9s - 672.9s]: nowhere in the Constitution that says we have to have uniformity. Pluralism is very important.

[672.9s - 677.8s]: This is what made the United States grow and be number one in scientists in research.

[678.7s - 683.4s]: We drew all the brains from the world to the United States to build a great society.

[683.9s - 685.3s]: And this is what we should have again.

[686.6s - 693.4s]: This is beautiful, Safi. I want to reference something you said a couple of minutes ago.

[693.6s - 701.6s]: This notion of loving our neighbor really is something that's calling us to act. It's something

[701.6s - 709.5s]: that's calling us to be outward in our service really. I'm sure what might you share with folks,

[709.6s - 715.9s]: regular folks, in terms of things we can do in our day-to-day lives to connect more with our

[715.9s - 724.9s]: neighbors and to show love more with our neighbors. The United States, I knew in many places,

[725.0s - 730.0s]: it still is the same. People say good morning when they see you in the street in the morning.

[730.6s - 735.7s]: I love this. If we start our day by saying good morning to our neighbor, that's a good start.

[736.9s - 741.1s]: In some other places in the world, people stop saying good morning to their neighbors.

[742.0s - 749.8s]: If we smile when we see our neighbor, it's a great start. If we put our self in the shoes of

[749.8s - 755.5s]: our immediate neighbors, that will be very good. If we feel with them, if we visit them when they're

[755.5s - 762.5s]: sick, if we take some soup to them when we have fresh soup done. If we have an older neighbor,

[762.5s - 770.1s]: if we visit her all the time, we're talking about loving the widows and the orphans and trying to

[770.1s - 775.8s]: free the oppressed. This is what Jesus talked about. This is what the Quran talks about. We have the

[775.8s - 782.1s]: same message. Look, I challenge everybody. If those messages are from God, then the message should

[782.1s - 789.1s]: be the same. If the message is the same, then go read your Bible and treat me as if I was

[789.7s - 796.4s]: just another Christian. I would love it. I will treat you like you were another Muslim. You would

[796.4s - 802.9s]: love it too. We're not that weird, really. You don't have to pray the way I pray. You don't have to

[802.9s - 809.7s]: fast the way I fast. You don't have to, but we have to treat each other as a human being with people

[809.7s - 817.5s]: with dignity. We need to treat each other with respect. As co-citizen, we are both citizen of a great

[817.5s - 823.9s]: country. We can build that country together. If we are united, if we are divided, we're allowing

[823.9s - 830.8s]: enemies of the United States to come in between us. We need to seal those gaps that exist.

[831.6s - 837.7s]: Hey, Trich, should not exist. We should replace them with love. If we claim to follow Jesus,

[838.2s - 844.4s]: Jesus talked about love, not alienation, reconciliation. That's what we need to do.

[844.9s - 851.5s]: Absolutely. Thank you. That's so beautiful. I just want to mention for our listeners who might

[851.5s - 859.4s]: be tuning in through the podcast. If you'd like, you can go to wyonorth.org and check out our community

[859.4s - 867.5s]: page. We also are running some special deals on our audiobooks. If you use the word podcast as

[867.5s - 875.4s]: your code, you'll get some discounts. I just want to be sure to mention that. I am struck by

[875.4s - 882.9s]: your connection between this notion of human responsibilities accompanying human rights.

[882.9s - 890.9s]: Also, between notions of classical understanding in our Abrahamic religious traditions,

[891.6s - 902.0s]: Islam, Christianity, Judaism, and classical understandings of the cultural infrastructure that

[902.0s - 909.5s]: exists in the United States. That is part of the deliberate founding of this country. Perhaps you

[909.5s - 919.4s]: can connect some of those dots together for us. Yes. I was born in Lebanon. I moved to the United

[919.4s - 925.6s]: States in 1969. I moved to permanent in the United States in 1969. The reason I moved to the United

[925.6s - 933.5s]: States is because I read somewhere that it's a country of neighbors. That might be a silly reason

[933.5s - 940.2s]: for some people. But for me, it was something very important. I wanted to live somewhere where my

[940.2s - 947.7s]: neighbors cared about me and I cared for them. Sure enough, when I first came in, I moved to Birmingham,

[948.1s - 955.4s]: Alabama. My neighbors were great. They were exactly what I was dreaming to have. They treated me like

[955.4s - 962.5s]: I'm one of the family. The door was always open. I was always welcome. Coffee was always warm.

[964.3s - 970.7s]: They shared with me their life. I shared my life with them. They gave me opportunities to succeed.

[971.6s - 975.9s]: Without my neighbors, I would never succeed it. Then I moved from there to New Orleans.

[976.8s - 983.8s]: New Orleans, Louisiana, of course. I lived there for 18 years. People of New Orleans were fantastic.

[983.8s - 989.7s]: They were great. They were loving. They were neighborly. We all cared about each other.

[991.2s - 996.6s]: The TV, the radio stations, the newspapers. We're always talking to me.

[997.9s - 1004.0s]: Asking me about things they don't understand about them at least. Trying to have a conversation about

[1004.0s - 1013.3s]: who are the Arabs? Who are the Israelis? Why do you have a conflict? Who are the Muslims? Who are

[1013.3s - 1020.1s]: the conversations? We can build a strong community if we sit down and talk to each other. We gain

[1020.1s - 1026.3s]: nothing but hating the other, fearing the other and hiding away from the other. We need to sit

[1026.3s - 1032.6s]: together, get to know each other. Look each other in the eyes, love each other, care about each other.

[1032.9s - 1038.4s]: This is how we can build a strong nation. And United States, I tell you, although we have a

[1038.4s - 1044.2s]: separation of church and state in the United States, but our constitution is built, it's based,

[1044.7s - 1053.1s]: on encouraging people to have faith. The government need to stay away from my personal beliefs.

[1053.6s - 1059.6s]: But it need to protect my personal beliefs. And that makes United States a very unique place.

[1060.2s - 1065.6s]: The American constitution is something that I and my children and my grandchildren

[1066.3s - 1072.7s]: is something that we are ready to die for. It's worth living for and dying for. It's a unique

[1073.5s - 1079.8s]: document. None like it exists in the world. Nobody else has a constitution like the American

[1079.8s - 1087.0s]: constitution. So United States really as a whole, as a country, can offer the world two things.

[1088.0s - 1093.6s]: The evangelical can go to the rest of the world and talk about Jesus and we can go and offer

[1093.6s - 1099.1s]: the constitution of the United States to help other people build democracies like ours.

[1099.6s - 1106.8s]: Not that our democracy is so perfect. It's looking less perfect every day now. But we need to fight

[1106.8s - 1116.4s]: again to make it perfect. We have the opportunity to fight to have the democracy, the republic, actually.

[1116.8s - 1122.0s]: We don't, our founding father fought to build a republic. That's what we need to rebuild again.

[1122.0s - 1128.5s]: In a republic, minorities count as well as majority. In a democracy, only that the majority come.

[1128.9s - 1133.6s]: No, not that not the minority. But in United States, we need to build a republic.

[1134.1s - 1140.9s]: Our founding father intended to build. And this is how I see my faith. I see my faith and love in

[1140.9s - 1146.9s]: my neighbor, but by providing my neighbors with the same freedoms I like to have for myself.

[1147.6s - 1152.7s]: I love for my neighbor what I love for myself. And the essence of all this is freedoms.

[1153.5s - 1160.2s]: If we don't have those freedoms, my love for my neighbor is limited. It's not potent.

[1161.4s - 1168.4s]: Yeah, doesn't lead to anything positive and good. So we need those freedoms in order to give meaning

[1169.3s - 1176.4s]: to loving our neighbors. It's so beautiful, Safiya. It reminds me of a story, a place that I

[1176.9s - 1182.9s]: read about when I was researching Y on Earth. And in many parts of our world right now, we're experiencing

[1183.9s - 1190.0s]: political conflict, cultural conflict. And of course, increasingly in some areas, we are seeing

[1190.0s - 1196.7s]: environmental challenges emerging as well. And all these things are colliding and creating

[1196.7s - 1203.3s]: conflicts and very difficult situations for many of our brothers and sisters on the planet right now.

[1203.9s - 1210.4s]: And I was struck coming across this example of a place, a simple place in Israel called the

[1210.4s - 1216.8s]: Arabah Institute where they are bringing together Palestinian youth and young adults,

[1217.4s - 1224.5s]: Israeli youth and young adults, others, Jews, Christians, Muslims, and not only are they doing

[1224.5s - 1230.8s]: cultural healing and reconciliation, they are also working with the land, with the soil, healing

[1231.4s - 1237.1s]: the land and the soil in a region of the world where there is a whole lot of healing to be done.

[1237.2s - 1243.4s]: And I'm just curious from your perspective, seeing love as being so central, seeing freedom as

[1243.4s - 1248.6s]: being so central when we're talking in the context of stewardship and sustainability,

[1249.4s - 1256.7s]: what do you think are some of the opportunities that people and communities all over have to do more

[1256.7s - 1263.5s]: in this respect? Well, a whole lot need to be done everywhere in the world. You mentioned

[1264.3s - 1269.5s]: work that's done in Israel. I think this kind of work that you're talking about is well needed.

[1270.4s - 1278.5s]: For years, I worked with many Israeli friends who are peace loving people about bringing peace

[1278.5s - 1284.5s]: into the holy land. After all, it is the holy land, you know, it should be blessed with peace.

[1285.2s - 1292.8s]: So far, we haven't been able to do anything substantial that we can show to the rest of the world.

[1293.9s - 1302.7s]: At this time, politics is taking away the best that we can promise, we can offer.

[1303.3s - 1311.4s]: Believe me, peace can be at hand. If the will for peace, especially on the Israeli side, because

[1311.4s - 1319.1s]: this is the strong side, you cannot ask the weak, the oppressed, the dominated, the conquered

[1319.9s - 1326.2s]: to come and sit with you and be on equal footage with you. If Israel want to give the Palestinian,

[1326.2s - 1333.2s]: their independent state, they can do that overnight. They don't need to ask permission from anybody.

[1333.8s - 1340.1s]: They can do it. And I usually use to put on the table a plan, an independent Palestinian state

[1340.1s - 1347.5s]: that go into affideration with Israel the next day. So become independent, have an identity

[1347.5s - 1355.8s]: called an Palestinian, and then go into affideration with Israel, because Palestine alone, the West Bank

[1355.8s - 1361.6s]: and Gaza alone, cannot make a living, cannot survive. They can only survive if their economy

[1361.6s - 1369.6s]: is attached to Israel. Israel will continue to exert lots of influence on its neighbor.

[1370.5s - 1378.2s]: But give them a promise, give them hope, give them something to live for. So they don't be as desperate

[1378.2s - 1384.8s]: as they are today. I mean, we're seeing people dying at the at the fence, a barbed wire fence,

[1384.8s - 1390.1s]: in Gaza every day. Why are they doing this? They're young people. They're dying because they're

[1390.1s - 1396.2s]: tired of being imprisoned without any hope, without any promise or anything good to happen to them.

[1396.9s - 1406.5s]: So please take them back, hug them, adapt them, show them a good life, show them some hope for a good

[1406.5s - 1412.9s]: life. And then they'll be your neighbor, they'll be your friends forever. But to keep them like this

[1412.9s - 1419.5s]: imprisoned, two million of them in a place where they cannot leave, nobody can come and visit them,

[1419.9s - 1425.4s]: they cannot even buy enough medication for their wounded. That's not you man, that's not good.

[1426.1s - 1433.2s]: I like for Israel to take the responsibility of putting together without negotiating, we don't

[1433.2s - 1439.8s]: need to negotiate. They are the strong party that can create facts on the ground like they used to

[1439.8s - 1446.1s]: proud to say all the time. For 70 years, they used to say to us, we create facts on the ground.

[1446.4s - 1452.2s]: Well, go ahead and do it. There is this final fact you need to create. Create an independent

[1452.2s - 1459.9s]: Palestinian state that will join you later in a federation. So you can all be a model for peace,

[1460.3s - 1465.9s]: for prosperity. The Bible says Israel should be a blessing to its neighbors. Be that blessing,

[1465.9s - 1472.7s]: forgot say, we want you in the neighborhood now. We accepted you. The days when we used to think

[1472.7s - 1479.6s]: that Israelis are not wanted over there are over with. Now you're part of them at least.

[1480.3s - 1487.0s]: You're part of us. We want you as our neighbors. But you need to feel like we do. You need to be

[1487.0s - 1492.7s]: a part of the neighborhood. Accept your Palestinian neighbors. Give them their own dignity.

[1492.7s - 1499.4s]: Treat them like normal human beings with the right for self-determination. They're under occupation

[1499.4s - 1504.0s]: now for how long? How long are they going to be under occupation forever? You cannot keep

[1504.0s - 1510.2s]: occupying another people forever. So this is basically where this work you talked about,

[1510.6s - 1520.9s]: love, cooperation, working together, building values. It's so important. We can promote values.

[1520.9s - 1529.1s]: If we promote values, everybody will have a better life. We are getting away from that in the United

[1529.1s - 1537.9s]: States, slowly but surely. Even evangelicals who talk about following Jesus, they're talking about

[1539.0s - 1545.3s]: the idea but losing the essence which is the values. The value is to love your neighbor.

[1546.0s - 1552.1s]: The value is to sacrifice for your neighbor. We forgot to say even rejecting refugees.

[1552.7s - 1559.2s]: We're rejecting people coming to us in peace, want our protection and want to work in the United

[1559.2s - 1570.5s]: States because we have values. So allow them to come in. But anyway, this is the point you raise

[1570.5s - 1578.4s]: is needed all over the world. Thank you, Sofis. It's so wonderful to hear from you and hear your

[1579.2s - 1587.6s]: perspective which I think for a lot of our listeners is a perspective that they're probably not

[1588.6s - 1594.3s]: exposed to or experiencing every day. And so it's such a joy, a privilege and an honor to be able

[1594.3s - 1598.7s]: to share this with folks. And I think we're going to wrap up here in just a minute

[1599.5s - 1607.2s]: before wrapping up. I just want to tease out again this focus, this emphasis on love, on our freedom,

[1607.8s - 1614.0s]: on cultivating our will and service to the brotherhood, the sisterhood of humanity. And

[1614.0s - 1622.3s]: we have so much we can do in our own neighborhoods and more broadly to help relieve suffering and

[1622.3s - 1630.4s]: cultivate love with people. And I just want to thank you again, Sofis, for joining us. And if you

[1630.4s - 1636.2s]: have any closing message for the audience at the Y on Earth community, it'd be wonderful if you

[1636.2s - 1644.2s]: could share that with us. Only few words. Love will win at the end. This, this, the essence of life on

[1644.2s - 1653.9s]: Earth is love. But love alone without us feeling it and sharing it and spreading it around is

[1653.9s - 1661.0s]: meaningless. Love is to be shared. So let's share love instead of hatred. Thank you.

[1661.5s - 1667.8s]: Beautiful. Thank you, Safi. Have a wonderful day, my friend. And I look forward to talking with you soon.

[1668.5s - 1668.9s]: Thank you.

segments.text: Hi friends, welcome to another edition of the Why on Earth communities stewardship and sustainability
series. I'm so excited to have the opportunity today to speak with Dr. Sapi Koskas who joins us from
Jeddah, Saudi Arabia, and Dr. Koskas travels all over the world speaking with political leaders,
business leaders, and religious and spiritual leaders about a variety of essential topics to our
time. In particular, he is doing work in the arena of cultural reconciliation,
of focusing on healing and love between and among different peoples and cultures,
and Sapi is such an honor and a pleasure to have this time with you today. Thank you so much for
joining us. Thank you. I'm very happy to be able to speak to you. Thank you.
Well, this is wonderful. I thought as a way to kick things off, I might mention to our viewers that
Sapi co-authored a translation of the Quran with David Hungerford, and in it they,
in their dedication, share a message I think that is so important to our times. I'm just going to
read this really fast. It says this translation of the Quran is dedicated to our grandchildren,
half of them Muslim, half of them Christian. If we as their adults do not learn how to live,
love, and respect each other, and to pass this on to them and their parents, we will have allowed
them to learn all the hate and fear that is so dominant in the world today. It is said that people
fear what they don't understand. We pray that this translation of the Quran with references to the
Bible will enable our grandchildren to share our understanding of the peaceful and inclusive
holy books of the religions claimed by more than half the people on the planet, both of which promote
God's love and mercy to all human beings. So Sapi, with that perhaps you could give us a bit of an
introduction to the work that you're doing right now around the world and why it's so important.
Well, I like to tell you a little bit about the translation to start with because that's the
foundation of the work that I do. Actually, I spent six years working on the translation of the
Quran. The reason I work on a new translation, there are over 200 translations you can find in any
bookstore. The reason I did a new translation is simply because I didn't recognize the verses they
are quoting on TV when they say this is the Quran. They talk about hateful things, they talk about how
we're asked to kill all the infidels. The Quran doesn't ask me to do this, that's not the Quran I
grew up with. So I decided enough is enough. I better do a translation in simple, easy to read,
easy to understand English. So my translation is not directed, it's not targeting academic people,
it's targeting my grandchildren and their friends. I really wanted them to understand
the faith I have. I wanted them to be proud of the faith I have, rather than be ashamed of it.
If my faith was something to be ashamed of, I would have left it myself. My faith includes
believing in Jesus, my faith includes believing in Moses, believing in Abraham. Their faith is my
faith. I don't have any faith coming from a different planet. I have a faith made for people
who live on planet Earth. And this faith calls us to build bridges, rather than build walls around us.
So I go around the world talking about what I found in those six years in the Quran. I thought I
know the Quran very well. After six years working, trying to understand every word in Arabic,
then finding an equivalent of that word in English, I think I know pretty well what the Quran's
message is. The essence of the Quran is freedom. The essence is God telling us, you come to me with
your free will, or I don't want you. Come to me freely. Submit your will to mine freely. Love each other
freely. Do good work on Earth freely. Only this word that you do with your free will that come.
And then at the end you come back to me. And I'm going to hold you responsible for whether you
loved each other, whether you loved your neighbors, whether you loved your enemies, whether you lived
in peace, or whether you worked for peace. It's not always possible for us to live in peace, but at least
we can work for peace. So this is basically what I go around the world talking about.
It's a message of bringing people together, reconciling, everybody talking about love rather than hatred.
It's so important. It's so important in these times, in particular, Safi. And you know, I'm struck
following your posts on Facebook and you are so good at documenting your journeys, your travels,
your encounters with different people all around the world. And I remember I think this was
earlier this year, maybe last year, a few months ago, seeing that at one part of the week you were
meeting with some spiritual leaders in the Middle East. And then later a few days later you were
meeting with some of the elders of the Mormon Church, probably I'm assuming out in Utah, I think it was.
Yes, a brilliant young university and other places.
Yes, and I was just so struck by when you mentioned bridge building that you are helping to plant
the seeds of these conversations of love and peace in so many communities all over. And that
when we get down to it, love and peace seem to be so central to these rich, religious and spiritual
traditions that we have the opportunity to draw from. And I'm curious, when you're bringing that
message to different communities, Safi, how is that received? How are people responding to that?
People listen to me attentively. I've never had anybody violently oppose what I'm saying.
I'm talking about basically loving God and loving neighbor. That's the essential message
that I bring to others, especially in United States. We need that message. We need to implement that
message. I mean, at one time I heard love God and love neighbor so much from my neighbors.
So I went and did a little survey knocked on the door of every neighbor I have on a short street
that I live on in the Washington DC area. And I said, do you love your neighbor? Say yes. How do you
love your neighbor? They didn't know how to answer. What do you do? How do you express this love?
Most people didn't know how to answer the question. So talking about loving neighbor is one thing.
Practicing loving our neighbor is another thing. Let alone loving our enemies. We are far away
from loving our enemies. We are so scared in the Western world in general, not just in United States,
of the other. We're scared of the other. There is an industry that keeps feeding fear into us.
One day I was speaking at a church in noon, in Georgia. And this old lady said, you said,
do you live in Saudi Arabia? I said, yes. She said, would you tell me that truth? I said, yes.
She said, is it true they're building boats and distributing weapons and they're going to come
to our shores and shoot us? I said, man, the Saudi people are really just like us. They have families,
they have children. They don't have time to think about us. They spend their time taking the
children to school, going to the doctor, trying to make a living, buying groceries from the grocery
store. They don't think much about us. You need to go and visit them. She said, is it safe to go there?
I said, yes, it is safe. Thousands of Americans come and visit and then go back safely.
It's very safe. So anyway, the message that I take to people is a message of love. The message
they receive from some network, TV networks and from radios, especially on the radio in the afternoon,
those talk shows their message of fears. They try to make people feel so fearful of the other.
So now in the mind of some Americans, all Muslims are terrorists. Every Muslim is a suspect.
Anybody speaking a language other than English is a suspect. This is not the way United States
used to be. I came to United States in 1968. I'm a bicentennial citizen. I became a citizen in 1976.
So I am very proud to say this and to repeat it. The United States I lived in at that time
is not the same as the United States we live in today. Most likely people had racism,
but it wasn't open. It wasn't obvious. They didn't share it openly.
Now the atmosphere is kind of poison and I don't like this. I don't like to see this. I don't
know what kind of place it's going to be for my grandchildren to grow in. I mean, we live there.
You know, I'm here today, but my home is not here. It is in the Washington DC area. This is where I live.
So, you know, it's just I care about what happens there. I want it to be a pluralistic country,
not a diverse country. I know a street in Maryland where you have a Jewish synagogue, a Catholic church,
a Baptist church and a Hindu temple, but those guys don't know each other. That street has diversity,
but doesn't have pluralism. People don't talk to each other. I want Americans to sit together with
each other and say, this is what I believe in and I have the Constitution to protect me.
So let me explain to you my beliefs. Regardless whether you agree with them or not,
nowhere in the Constitution that says we have to have uniformity. Pluralism is very important.
This is what made the United States grow and be number one in scientists in research.
We drew all the brains from the world to the United States to build a great society.
And this is what we should have again.
This is beautiful, Safi. I want to reference something you said a couple of minutes ago.
This notion of loving our neighbor really is something that's calling us to act. It's something
that's calling us to be outward in our service really. I'm sure what might you share with folks,
regular folks, in terms of things we can do in our day-to-day lives to connect more with our
neighbors and to show love more with our neighbors. The United States, I knew in many places,
it still is the same. People say good morning when they see you in the street in the morning.
I love this. If we start our day by saying good morning to our neighbor, that's a good start.
In some other places in the world, people stop saying good morning to their neighbors.
If we smile when we see our neighbor, it's a great start. If we put our self in the shoes of
our immediate neighbors, that will be very good. If we feel with them, if we visit them when they're
sick, if we take some soup to them when we have fresh soup done. If we have an older neighbor,
if we visit her all the time, we're talking about loving the widows and the orphans and trying to
free the oppressed. This is what Jesus talked about. This is what the Quran talks about. We have the
same message. Look, I challenge everybody. If those messages are from God, then the message should
be the same. If the message is the same, then go read your Bible and treat me as if I was
just another Christian. I would love it. I will treat you like you were another Muslim. You would
love it too. We're not that weird, really. You don't have to pray the way I pray. You don't have to
fast the way I fast. You don't have to, but we have to treat each other as a human being with people
with dignity. We need to treat each other with respect. As co-citizen, we are both citizen of a great
country. We can build that country together. If we are united, if we are divided, we're allowing
enemies of the United States to come in between us. We need to seal those gaps that exist.
Hey, Trich, should not exist. We should replace them with love. If we claim to follow Jesus,
Jesus talked about love, not alienation, reconciliation. That's what we need to do.
Absolutely. Thank you. That's so beautiful. I just want to mention for our listeners who might
be tuning in through the podcast. If you'd like, you can go to wyonorth.org and check out our community
page. We also are running some special deals on our audiobooks. If you use the word podcast as
your code, you'll get some discounts. I just want to be sure to mention that. I am struck by
your connection between this notion of human responsibilities accompanying human rights.
Also, between notions of classical understanding in our Abrahamic religious traditions,
Islam, Christianity, Judaism, and classical understandings of the cultural infrastructure that
exists in the United States. That is part of the deliberate founding of this country. Perhaps you
can connect some of those dots together for us. Yes. I was born in Lebanon. I moved to the United
States in 1969. I moved to permanent in the United States in 1969. The reason I moved to the United
States is because I read somewhere that it's a country of neighbors. That might be a silly reason
for some people. But for me, it was something very important. I wanted to live somewhere where my
neighbors cared about me and I cared for them. Sure enough, when I first came in, I moved to Birmingham,
Alabama. My neighbors were great. They were exactly what I was dreaming to have. They treated me like
I'm one of the family. The door was always open. I was always welcome. Coffee was always warm.
They shared with me their life. I shared my life with them. They gave me opportunities to succeed.
Without my neighbors, I would never succeed it. Then I moved from there to New Orleans.
New Orleans, Louisiana, of course. I lived there for 18 years. People of New Orleans were fantastic.
They were great. They were loving. They were neighborly. We all cared about each other.
The TV, the radio stations, the newspapers. We're always talking to me.
Asking me about things they don't understand about them at least. Trying to have a conversation about
who are the Arabs? Who are the Israelis? Why do you have a conflict? Who are the Muslims? Who are
the conversations? We can build a strong community if we sit down and talk to each other. We gain
nothing but hating the other, fearing the other and hiding away from the other. We need to sit
together, get to know each other. Look each other in the eyes, love each other, care about each other.
This is how we can build a strong nation. And United States, I tell you, although we have a
separation of church and state in the United States, but our constitution is built, it's based,
on encouraging people to have faith. The government need to stay away from my personal beliefs.
But it need to protect my personal beliefs. And that makes United States a very unique place.
The American constitution is something that I and my children and my grandchildren
is something that we are ready to die for. It's worth living for and dying for. It's a unique
document. None like it exists in the world. Nobody else has a constitution like the American
constitution. So United States really as a whole, as a country, can offer the world two things.
The evangelical can go to the rest of the world and talk about Jesus and we can go and offer
the constitution of the United States to help other people build democracies like ours.
Not that our democracy is so perfect. It's looking less perfect every day now. But we need to fight
again to make it perfect. We have the opportunity to fight to have the democracy, the republic, actually.
We don't, our founding father fought to build a republic. That's what we need to rebuild again.
In a republic, minorities count as well as majority. In a democracy, only that the majority come.
No, not that not the minority. But in United States, we need to build a republic.
Our founding father intended to build. And this is how I see my faith. I see my faith and love in
my neighbor, but by providing my neighbors with the same freedoms I like to have for myself.
I love for my neighbor what I love for myself. And the essence of all this is freedoms.
If we don't have those freedoms, my love for my neighbor is limited. It's not potent.
Yeah, doesn't lead to anything positive and good. So we need those freedoms in order to give meaning
to loving our neighbors. It's so beautiful, Safiya. It reminds me of a story, a place that I
read about when I was researching Y on Earth. And in many parts of our world right now, we're experiencing
political conflict, cultural conflict. And of course, increasingly in some areas, we are seeing
environmental challenges emerging as well. And all these things are colliding and creating
conflicts and very difficult situations for many of our brothers and sisters on the planet right now.
And I was struck coming across this example of a place, a simple place in Israel called the
Arabah Institute where they are bringing together Palestinian youth and young adults,
Israeli youth and young adults, others, Jews, Christians, Muslims, and not only are they doing
cultural healing and reconciliation, they are also working with the land, with the soil, healing
the land and the soil in a region of the world where there is a whole lot of healing to be done.
And I'm just curious from your perspective, seeing love as being so central, seeing freedom as
being so central when we're talking in the context of stewardship and sustainability,
what do you think are some of the opportunities that people and communities all over have to do more
in this respect? Well, a whole lot need to be done everywhere in the world. You mentioned
work that's done in Israel. I think this kind of work that you're talking about is well needed.
For years, I worked with many Israeli friends who are peace loving people about bringing peace
into the holy land. After all, it is the holy land, you know, it should be blessed with peace.
So far, we haven't been able to do anything substantial that we can show to the rest of the world.
At this time, politics is taking away the best that we can promise, we can offer.
Believe me, peace can be at hand. If the will for peace, especially on the Israeli side, because
this is the strong side, you cannot ask the weak, the oppressed, the dominated, the conquered
to come and sit with you and be on equal footage with you. If Israel want to give the Palestinian,
their independent state, they can do that overnight. They don't need to ask permission from anybody.
They can do it. And I usually use to put on the table a plan, an independent Palestinian state
that go into affideration with Israel the next day. So become independent, have an identity
called an Palestinian, and then go into affideration with Israel, because Palestine alone, the West Bank
and Gaza alone, cannot make a living, cannot survive. They can only survive if their economy
is attached to Israel. Israel will continue to exert lots of influence on its neighbor.
But give them a promise, give them hope, give them something to live for. So they don't be as desperate
as they are today. I mean, we're seeing people dying at the at the fence, a barbed wire fence,
in Gaza every day. Why are they doing this? They're young people. They're dying because they're
tired of being imprisoned without any hope, without any promise or anything good to happen to them.
So please take them back, hug them, adapt them, show them a good life, show them some hope for a good
life. And then they'll be your neighbor, they'll be your friends forever. But to keep them like this
imprisoned, two million of them in a place where they cannot leave, nobody can come and visit them,
they cannot even buy enough medication for their wounded. That's not you man, that's not good.
I like for Israel to take the responsibility of putting together without negotiating, we don't
need to negotiate. They are the strong party that can create facts on the ground like they used to
proud to say all the time. For 70 years, they used to say to us, we create facts on the ground.
Well, go ahead and do it. There is this final fact you need to create. Create an independent
Palestinian state that will join you later in a federation. So you can all be a model for peace,
for prosperity. The Bible says Israel should be a blessing to its neighbors. Be that blessing,
forgot say, we want you in the neighborhood now. We accepted you. The days when we used to think
that Israelis are not wanted over there are over with. Now you're part of them at least.
You're part of us. We want you as our neighbors. But you need to feel like we do. You need to be
a part of the neighborhood. Accept your Palestinian neighbors. Give them their own dignity.
Treat them like normal human beings with the right for self-determination. They're under occupation
now for how long? How long are they going to be under occupation forever? You cannot keep
occupying another people forever. So this is basically where this work you talked about,
love, cooperation, working together, building values. It's so important. We can promote values.
If we promote values, everybody will have a better life. We are getting away from that in the United
States, slowly but surely. Even evangelicals who talk about following Jesus, they're talking about
the idea but losing the essence which is the values. The value is to love your neighbor.
The value is to sacrifice for your neighbor. We forgot to say even rejecting refugees.
We're rejecting people coming to us in peace, want our protection and want to work in the United
States because we have values. So allow them to come in. But anyway, this is the point you raise
is needed all over the world. Thank you, Sofis. It's so wonderful to hear from you and hear your
perspective which I think for a lot of our listeners is a perspective that they're probably not
exposed to or experiencing every day. And so it's such a joy, a privilege and an honor to be able
to share this with folks. And I think we're going to wrap up here in just a minute
before wrapping up. I just want to tease out again this focus, this emphasis on love, on our freedom,
on cultivating our will and service to the brotherhood, the sisterhood of humanity. And
we have so much we can do in our own neighborhoods and more broadly to help relieve suffering and
cultivate love with people. And I just want to thank you again, Sofis, for joining us. And if you
have any closing message for the audience at the Y on Earth community, it'd be wonderful if you
could share that with us. Only few words. Love will win at the end. This, this, the essence of life on
Earth is love. But love alone without us feeling it and sharing it and spreading it around is
meaningless. Love is to be shared. So let's share love instead of hatred. Thank you.
Beautiful. Thank you, Safi. Have a wonderful day, my friend. And I look forward to talking with you soon.
Thank you.
